'i am concerned when i see universities appearing to close down on open-minded discussion . censorship is now coming from the student body '
'my heart sank when i saw the vanity fair cover : it was both beautiful , glamorous , and deluding '

joan 's life lessons : 'willpower has got me further than talent '

documents.title: that 's all for today !
text: many thanks to everyone who posted questions , and to joan for her time and her generous answers .
until next time !
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:49pm time to go .
i 've enjoyed the challenge of talking to you all and each one of you .
goodbye .

documents.title: 'marriage vows are between two people , and the concern of those two people only '
text: sirisaac asks : do marriage vows mean anything ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:48pm vows matter to those who believe in them .
i think we all accept that to take an oath in a court of law binds us absolutely to tell the truth .
and indeed there is a punishment if we are found not to be doing so .
marriage vows are between two people , and the concern of those two people only .
if the vows are meaningful , then both parties will struggle to sustain them , even when the going gets rough .
but we live at a time when society agrees that people should not be forced to go on living unhappy lives .
at which point , marriage vows , however serious for those involved , will get broken .
all of this is painful , but if vows are to have meaning , then it should be painful .

documents.title: 'i am concerned when i see universities appearing to close down on open-minded discussion . censorship is now coming from the student body '
text: justinphillips asks : do you have any regrets about taboo ?
do you have any plans to bring it back ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:44pm i have absolutely no regrets about taboo .
what is interesting is how the parameters have shifted , and how words and attitudes that were acceptable even in the early noughties are unacceptable now .
as president of birkbeck , i am concerned when i see universities appearing to close down on open-minded discussion .
censorship is now coming from the student body , rather than from the grownups who used to dictate what was allowed .
students are now demanding restrictions on who speaks and what can be said .
the current row about cecil rhodes is a case in point .
nobody bothered with his statue ten years ago ; now people are finding it offensive and want it pulled down .
i sympathise with their point of view , but think personally there are much more important issues to feel anger about .
sidfishes asks : if the you that is now could go back in time and give one piece of advice to the you who was 18 what would it be ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:40pm i think i would say : be less fearful of failure .
as a young person i was well aware that if i failed exams , or failed my degree , i would lose the chance to shape my life as i wanted .
i now know that 's not true , that you can shape your life without toeing the line in a world shaped by the adults .
so more courage and independence !
furiouspurpose asks : which brand of bakewell tart would you recommend and why ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:39pm bakewell tart comes from bakewell , obviously .
there is a shop that sells something called bakewell pudding , which claims to be the original , and is very tasty .
a good bakewell tart with plenty of almond and raspberry jam is hard to beat .
the ready made varieties are not as good as those made with love in a home kitchen .
sidfishes asks : when you are dreaming and you find yourself talking in that dream , do you talk in your original lancashire accent ?
[ actually , just realised stockport is in cheshire ! ]
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:38pm stockport is on the border between lancashire and cheshire , that border being the mersey river which runs straight through it .
i 'm not conscious of having much to say in my dreams .
i 'm usually too busy enjoying the landscape , or more commonly , escaping the catastrophes of nature and events that seem to pursue .
i had a terrible dream the other day of capsizing from a boat .
i think the immigration crisis had reached my subconscious .

furiouspurpose asks : do you think that , in retrospect , it was distasteful to complain about a potential mansion tax , when so many young people in london face poor standard , overpriced accommodation ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:36pm i never complained about the mansion tax .
what i did complain about was the phrase mansion tax was too forbidding for people to take on board .
even today , i am in favour of what i would call a windfall tax to be made on properties which enjoy a particularly steep rise in value .
i did nothing to add to the value of my house - it 's value is simply the result of the housing bubble .
so i do n't see why i should n't be liable to pay tax on what is a historical accident .
septredom asks : do you still enjoy living in primrose hill ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:32pm yes , i do .
i moved into my present house over fifty years ago .
the area was very run down , but we chose a place which had , under the soot , the merits of high ceilings and tall windows .
the ceilings and windows are still the same but the soot has gone .
it has been interesting to live through a lifetime within the same community , to see the shopkeepers grow old and the trendier boutiques arrive .
once there were grocers and butchers , now there are restaurants and cafes .
i 've been able to observe social change without leaving my house .
what can i expect of the next few years ?
heaven knows .
we are still a community that comes together to save its library , plant bulbs in the shared garden , and run our own film show .
chrisisamazing asks : do you want to be in my band ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:28pm robert plant is a neighbour of mine , and so it follows that i am a great enthusiast of led zeppelin .
i like heavy rock , but also the beatles , dylan but my knowledge stops there .
i ca n't see myself letting my hair down enough to be part of any such enterprise , though in my fantasies , it would figure highly .
the chance to be both talented and uninhibited did not come the way of my generation .
i envy the young for their freedom and joy in music .

documents.title: 'my heart sank when i saw the vanity fair cover : it was both beautiful , glamorous , and deluding '
text: pollycurtis asks : hello , i 'm fascinated by the vanity fair cover out today .
what do you think about the place of older women in hollywood ?
thanks !
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:27pm my heart sank when i saw the vanity fair cover : it was both beautiful , glamorous , and deluding .
each of these women is outstanding in her own right , and i felt that to parade them together diminished them .
but there 's no denying the high style of the photograph .
older women in hollywood , well , how about the title role of the lead in a romcom , the heroic figure who solves the mystery , the crusading champion who wins the day ?
any or all of those parts could be played by the likes of meryl streep , julianne moore , charlotte rampling , helen mirren , lily tomlin .
raoulchateaubriand asks : dear joan , you 've always struck me as someone singularly good at staying true to yourself .
might i ask , what is your secret and do you have any advice for young people still wondering what to do with their lives ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:24pm i have several grandchildren growing to maturity , and they do n't always want my advice .
but they still get it .
i try to encourage them to seek out what it is that would make them happy .
not tickets to a pop concert , or the latest in tattoos and piercings .
but some genuine way of expressing their lives in work with colleagues on some enterprise they would find rewarding .
the problem is young people are surrounded by so many options , they can be deluded by what seems trendy and flamboyant .
i would encourage them to think quietly and in private about what they think their lives might be about .
it 's not easy , but you grow to like yourself and to accept your place in the world .
amsams asks : always been someone i 've liked .
was going to ask what she thought of corbyn ?
possibly however , it wo n't be permitted , therefore i wo n't ask .
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:21pm i do n't know jeremy corbyn and have never met him .
whenever i read whatever he himself says , it seems enormously sensible .
i try not to get my impression of him filtered through the tory press , so it 's quite hard to know how to evaluate his impact in politics today with any clear sense of what is true .
i stand aside from what i 'm told are the inner struggles of the labour party because i hold fast to their founding beliefs in social justice and equality .
and that 's enough for me .
the right direction ?
forward !
i 'm proud of the fact that in the lords we have defeeated this government on ten occasions , each one a matter of personal concern for individual citizens .
we forced a rethink on tax credits , and recently voted against the department of work and pensions ' plans to cut the living allowance for the disabled .
could anything be more mean-spirited and niggardly ?
that 's where the labour peers are able to put a break on this government 's brutality .
krumstets asks : what lies at the heart of your matter ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:17pm heart of the matter was probably the favourite of all the series i made for television .
i liked the way i was invited to consider how public affairs impact on human lives , and how moral judgements should be brought to bear on public events .
i think my heart is really with this use of social justice as expressed in the lives of individual people and their struggles .
looking back , i can see that i 've always been drawn to and invited to present programmes that deal with personal dilemmas , or in the case of the arts , personal expression .
and i 'm happy with that .
at the end of the day , i can sleep soundly with the sense of a job well done .
who needs to rise up some professional ladder and make a fortune ?
that 's the wrong way to go .
chattykathy14 asks : given your recent comments about how useful it is to be a member of the house of lords in filling up your spare time , could she possible recommend me for membership ?
i 'm at a bit of a loose end .
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:15pm i 'll certainly try .
in fact there is a process by which you can be nominated to be considered , and a committee assesses your qualifications .
having said that , we could do with some young blood , young talent , and people who know their way round modern technology .
so how about it ?
leonardodecaprio asks : stupid question i know , but given your surname , will you enter celebrity bake off ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:14pm bakewell is the surname i acquired in my first marriage - my original name was rowlands , which is no indication of my cooking skills .

i am a pretty good cook , but more at ease with old-fashioned dishes , like rice pudding and macaroni cheese , sunday roast and bread and butter pudding , than i am with new-fangled cooking and fancy icing .
so , no , i do n't think they 'll want me as one of their number .
mary berry flies the flag for us older women with enormous panache , and i admire her for that .
it sets an example for others the same age as we are to keep going .
tuffandstuffan asks : shakespeare or milton ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:11pm shakespeare .
by a long way .
milton is hard going , beautiful when you get there , but not easy to access .
shakespeare is simply sublime , and has been part of my life since i played hermia in midsummer night 's dream when i was 14 .
any production of shakespeare is worth seeing , and i 've seen several king lears and not enough comedy of errors .
we have such wonderful theatre in this country that it 's always a pleasure even if i do n't go along with the particular style of the director .
i have the sonnets on my kindle , so that whenever i 'm abroad or travelling , i can seek solace in their beauty .
the sonnet form is worth examining over and over .
some of the sonnets are very familiar , and familiarity is pleasing ; others are elusive and difficult , but worth persevering with .
i also love books about shakespeare : james shapiro 's two books are enthralling , i ca n't get enough of that sort of thing the background to his life and culture .

the cottage where i wrote stop the clocks is in warwickshire , not far from stratford-upon-avon , and when my writing had run into a blank wall , i would head off to the shakespeare memorial theatre to refresh the spirit .
i would return home singing .
biglampbitter2 asks : how annoyed were you by the phrase thinking mans totty ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:05pm it was `` thinking man 's crumpet '' i remember it well .
at the time , the mid-60s , i thought it was a casual piece of gallantry .
i had n't realised how it would linger on to haunt me and indeed hamper my chances to be a heavyweight journalist .
it labelled me as a featherbrain , and not as i wanted to be seen : a high-minded and serious journalist .
i was never part of the celebrity milieu .
nowadays , no-one would dream of using such a phrase without being savaged on twitter .
i could even bring a case of harassment !
angelblue asks : as mrs merton might have said : what do you think is the most attractive thing about joining the â£ 300-a-day house of lords ?

guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 2:02pm without sounding too much on the defensive , i should tell you that those of us who turn up for the house of lords regularly do a good deal of work .
much of it worthwhile and successful .
what 's more , plenty of people there could earn more in the outside world than attending the house of lords .

that 's not to say i do n't appreciate the chance to be there , join in the revision of the government 's legislation , and contribute via committee work to more thoughtful consideration of what 's going on in the country .
i sat on on the communications committee when we began to look at where leveson is now , and published a report that helped sustain an interest in what is still unfinished business .
also as a labour peer , i 'm proud that we were forceful enough to persuade george osborne to reconsider his ruling on tax credits - that was a great moment .

documents.title: 'for some thirty years now , i 've taken a 10-minute nap after lunch '
text: goldendays49 asks : how do you keep yourself awake in the afternoons , please ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 1:59pm i do n't .
for some thirty years now , i 've taken a 10-minute nap after lunch .
in fact it 's more than a nap - i can go into deep sleep for some 15 minutes and awake refreshed , to treat the afternoon like a new day .

documents.title: 'lunch with harold [ pinter ] was a constant pleasure and always full of laughter '
text: oneanothername asks : in the late night line up interview with harold pinter when you asked him about remembering conversation he told you the story of the couple making love , unseen , in the bandstand , in the moonlight .
the bloke walking by the bandstand says to his mate , ee , i 've had many a good shit in that bandstand .
was this autobiographical ?
i 've been waiting almost 50years to ask you about that interview !
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 1:58pm certainly not !
harold pinter was one of the most amusing companions i have ever known .
he was a brilliant raconteur and his friends loved his company .
he had an extraordinary wit and memory for quotations and occasions .
lunch with harold was a constant pleasure and always full of laughter .
his reputation as someone dour and bad-tempered refers only to his public persona ; as a person , his friends and family adored him .

documents.title: joan 's life lessons : 'willpower has got me further than talent '
text: here she is at guardian towers : beaumont-thomas and her first answer is for clareyesno , who asked : hi joan .
it says your book takes stock of what she has learned in her life what are the most valuable lessons you 've learned , that apply to pretty much anybody ?
how far do you think women in broadcasting have come , in terms of overcoming sexism and gaining equality , and where is there still work to be done ?
erm and what did you think when you first saw betrayal ?
was it painful to have that part of your life so out in the open ?
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 1:47pm well first of all , the person you can depend on most is yourself .
so do n't let the world put you down .
willpower has got me further than talent .
when i was younger i would n't take no for an answer ; persistence is a great virtue .
secondly , learn to value everything that comes your way , so you 're never disappointed by what each day holds .
once you earn a decent living , do n't bother about getting richer .
enjoy company , friendship , family and beauty .
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 1:53pm in a long life , i 've seen radical changes but it 's not enough .
there were women broadcasting before my time - a woman newsreader lasted six months .
there were women producers on panorama and tonight - none of them ever became editors but they were resolute , strong-minded and talented women but not many of them .
i got my breakthrough in the 60s by virtue of being on a daily programme which meant plenty of exposure to the audience .
i learned as i went along .
slowly and surely , women demonstrated they had as much talent as the men , and were every bit as resilient and determined .
but there is still a way to go .
simply seeing outstanding broadcasters on screen - lyse doucet , lindsey hilsum - does n't mean that back behind the screen there are their equivalent in top management .
measured in proportion , there are fewer women than men , and that needs to be remedied .
it will be soon i hope .
top management and frontline broadcasting is strenuous and needs a rigorous approach .
it 's no place for slackers .
again , willpower and persistence will count in your favour .
a little ruthlessness wo n't come amiss .
guardian contributor joanbakewell 02 february 2016 1:56pm harold pinter wrote betrayal years after our affair was over .
but we had remained friends and he always sent me his new plays .
betrayal arrived late one night , delivered by hand , so it was clearly special .
i read it that night , and i did n't sleep .
it is very shocking to find the events of your life spread out for the stage .
reading betrayal had been a huge shock , but he was keen i should go to the first night , so i steeled myself to face up to what was now a theatrical event .
i think i put my personal feelings aside for the sake of that opening night .
internally i was both confused and intrigued to see how ordinary events had been transmuted by him into a really intriguing play about human behaviour .
i think in the end i felt almost proud of its success .

documents.title: post your questions for joan bakewell
text: in a spectacular career spanning more than half a century , joan bakewell has been a tv presenter , a journalist , a novelist and a labour peer tasked with championing older people .
now 82 , she has left a lasting mark on broadcasting since she started out on the groundbreaking late night line-up , whose format of bickering culture-vultures endures to the present day .
her show heart of the matter went on to tweak the formula for current affairs , bringing knotty moral questions into living rooms nationwide .
her personal life was occasionally tempestuous harold pinter wrote his play betrayal about her affair with him and it all went into her autobiography the centre of the bed in 2004 .
following two novels and another memoir , she has now written stop the clocks , in which she takes stock of what she has learned in her life .
she is joining us to answer questions about anything in her life and career , in a live webchat from 1.40pm on tuesday 2 february .
post yours in the comments below , and she 'll take on as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The TV presenter recalls the lessons of a life in the spotlight in a new book, Stop the Clocks. She joined us to answer your questions in a live webchat from life and work lessons to the House of Lords via marriage and power naps, catch up with her answers here.
